content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. The conference includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference appoints advisory committees and includes ex officio members, such as the Member of the United States House of Representatives representing the basin's congressional district. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan within a year of the enactment of this section. The plan will clarify the responsibilities of Federal and State agencies and other individuals in addressing water pollution in the basin. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan within a year of enactment. The plan will outline responsibilities for Federal and State agencies and individuals in water pollution prevention and control activities, funding methods, and incorporation of environmental management concepts from State and Federal plans. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan within a year of enactment. The plan will include strategies for water pollution prevention and control in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, promoting pollution prevention and management practices. Public review and comment on the draft Plan will be facilitated by the Administrator in cooperation with the Management Conference. The Administrator will approve the pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin if it meets the requirements. Upon approval, the plan will be considered an approved management program and comprehensive conservation and management plan. Upon approval of the pollution prevention plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin, it will become an approved comprehensive conservation and management plan. The Administrator may provide grant assistance for the development of the plan to various agencies and organizations. The Administrator may provide grant assistance for the development of the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs, and non-Federal sources required to provide the remaining share. Terms and conditions for administration may be established by the Administrator. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for grants as deemed appropriate. The term 'Coeur d'Alene Basin' refers to a specific watershed in northern Idaho. This section does not affect the jurisdiction or powers of any US or State department, agency, or entity related to the Basin. The Environmental Protection Agency is authorized to receive necessary appropriations for fiscal years 1995-1999 to carry out the terms of the treaty or memorandum to which the United States is a signatory. SEC. 3. FEDERAL PROGRAM COORDINATION. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin as part of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. This collaboration involves working with universities, research institutions, and state agencies in Idaho and Washington. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with appropriate departments and agencies of Idaho and Washington, will develop an integrated geographic information system in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes converting partial recording sites to continuous monitoring stations with full gauging capabilities and establishing additional monitoring stations for data collection on groundwater mapping, water quality, and sediment. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service, in cooperation with the Coeur d'Alene Fish and Wildlife Management Cooperative, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program as part of a water quality and sediment data collection effort in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The restoration, development, and conservation program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin will include dedicating hatchery production at or above pre-Act levels and conducting a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey. The restoration, development, and conservation program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes listing threatened and endangered species, migratory bird populations survey, and activities to accomplish program purposes. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving the health of fishery resources, conducting investigations on fishery resources status, disseminating information, and surveying fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of Appropriations: The Department of the Interior is authorized to receive necessary funds for fiscal years 1995-1999 to carry out activities related to improving fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin to reduce human and environmental risks. Develop and maintain a computerized geographical information system inventory of abandoned or inactive mining sites and contaminated areas in the Basin, including audits, tailing piles, mill sites, and processing facilities. Provide cleanup and restoration of mining contaminated sites on public lands in the Basin. Develop and implement stream and river restoration. Develop and implement stream and river restoration plans in the Basin, including rebuilding stream structure, wood debris placement, habitat structures, stabilization of banks, and riparian plantings. Monitor restored areas to assess effectiveness and address any residual problems. Collaborate with other agencies, the Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, regulators, and landowners to develop and implement a land management plan. Develop and implement a land management plan for public lands and other lands in the Basin to reduce human health and environmental risks. Maintain an integrated geographical information system of cultural and ecological resources, contaminated areas, and restoration activities. Collaborate with various agencies and wildlife interests to develop wildlife conservation efforts. The Indian tribe and wildlife interests collaborate to develop wildlife and fishery habitat management plans for the Basin, including monitoring for effectiveness. They also work with various agencies to develop an integrated public recreation management plan. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection and inventory of mining waste in the Basin to support the development of an integrated public recreation management plan and a lake and river information program. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory, and management of mining waste for restoration projects and contaminated lands. This includes designing, constructing, and overseeing repositories for mine waste and contaminated soil needed for restoration activities. Authorization of Appropriations.--Funding is authorized for the Bureau of Land Management to carry out restoration activities, lake and river information programs, long-term land management plans, and maintenance of restored public lands for fiscal years 1995-2002. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
